2.text: Oh that my grief were thoroughly weighed, and my calamity laid in the balances together!

3.text: For now it would be heavier than the sand of the sea: therefore my words are swallowed up.

4.text: For the arrows of the Almighty are within me, the poison of which drinketh up my spirit: the terrors of God set themselves in array against me.

5.text: Doth the wild ass bray when he hath grass? or loweth the ox over his fodder?

6.text: Can that which is unsavory be eaten without salt? or is there any taste in the white of an egg?

7.text: The things that my soul refused to touch are as my sorrowful food.

8.text: Oh that I might have my request; and that God would grant me the thing that I long for!

9.text: Even that it would please God to destroy me; that he would let loose his hand, and cut me off!

10.text: Then should I yet have comfort; yes, I would harden myself in sorrow: let him not spare; for I have not concealed the words of the Holy One.

11.text: What is my strength, that I should hope? and what is my end, that I should prolong my life?

12.text: Is my strength the strength of stones? or is my flesh of brass?

13.text: Is not my help in me? and is wisdom driven quite from me?

14.text: To him that is afflicted pity should be shown from his friend; but he forsaketh the fear of the Almighty.

15.text: My brethren have dealt deceitfully as a brook, and as the stream of brooks they pass away;

16.text: Which are blackish by reason of the ice, and in which the snow is hid:

17.text: In the time when they become warm, they vanish: when it is hot, they are consumed out of their place.

18.text: The paths of their way are turned aside; they go to nothing, and perish.

19.text: The troops of Tema looked, the companies of Sheba waited for them.

20.text: They were confounded because they had hoped; they came thither, and were ashamed.

21.text: For now ye are nothing: ye see my casting down, and are afraid.

22.text: Did I say, Bring to me? or Give a reward for me of your substance?

23.text: Or, Deliver me from the enemyâ€™s hand? or, Redeem me from the hand of the mighty?

24.text: Teach me, and I will hold my tongue: and cause me to understand in what I have erred.

25.text: How forcible are right words! but what doth your arguing reprove?

26.text: Do ye imagine to reprove words, and the speeches of one that is desperate, which are as wind?

27.text: Yes, ye overwhelm the fatherless, and ye dig a pit for your friend.

28.text: Now therefore be content, look upon me; for it is evident to you if I lie.

29.text: Return, I pray you, let it not be iniquity; yes, return again, my righteousness is in it.

30.text: Is there iniquity in my tongue? cannot my taste discern perverse things?
